story.storykicker: The online registration process for more than 60,000 seats will start from Wednesday at 12 and will continue till June 19.
story.storybody:
The much-awaited under-graduate admissions to one of the most prestigious Universities will kick off from Wednesday. Promoting the concept of 'Digital India', the Delhi University has gone entirely online this year. From filling up the application forms to depositing the fees, the University has gone hi-tech.

The online registration process for more than 60,000 seats will start from Wednesday at 12 and will continue till June 19. The first cut-off list will be announced on June 27, and unlike previous years the varsity will release only five cut-off lists. "The University has decided to make the entire process online this year.

Till last year, the students had the option of filling u the forms offline too. We have also gone beyond Delhi; we have introduced five more cities. Our aim is to make the process error-free," said Professor Tarun Kumar Das, registrar, Delhi University. The students will have three days to complete the enrollment process following the publication of each list.

Rules and relaxation

The merit lists for the remaining seats -after admissions close for the fifth cut-off -will be announced by respective colleges. The centralised Optical Mark Recognition (OMR) forms will be available on Delhi University's website www.du.ac.in and students will have to make the payment through Internet banking. The fee for General category students is  Rs 100 whereas for SC/ST students the admission form will cost Rs 50.

From this year, the relaxation to girls' students in Delhi University colleges has been fixed to one percent, which was between 1-3 per cent till last year. Also, for the first time, the University will consider Kashmiri migrants from over the country and give five per cent relaxation to the students. The varsity has also scrapped the 10-marks deduction criteria for students with theory and practical courses. From this year, the varsity will calculate the marks on pro-rata basis. Many State boards like Rajasthan Board, Haryana Board, Madhya Pradesh Board and others have allotted 60 marks for theory and 40 marks for practical.

Also read: Post Graduation programme of DU recieves 1.29 lakh applications
